newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ SPORT - AB'S RETURN TO BASICS FREED UP CULLEN.
newsitem.headline: NZ SPORT - AB'S RETURN TO BASICS FREED UP CULLEN.

text.p: WELLINGTON, Aug 11 - A return to the basics by the All Blacks freed brilliant attacking fullback Christian Cullen to get back to his best against South Africa on Saturday, NZPA reports.
Cullen scored two tries and had a hand in a couple more simply because he was given the ball quicker and at pace during the All Blacks' 55-35 tri-series win at Auckland's Eden Park.
He has scored 17 tries in 17 tests and is chasing team-mates Jeff Wilson on 21 and Frank Bunce on 20.
John Kirwan holds the All Blacks' all-time try-scoring record with 35, followed by Wilson, Bunce, and then Cullen, who is tied in third place with Zinzan Brooke.
"We've been working all week on the presentation of the ball, getting the passes in front, so we don't have to stop and catch them and then run," said Cullen.
"It seemed to work pretty well out there."
The All Blacks often passed across second five-eighth Alama Ieremia to give centre Bunce a crack at opposing centre Percy Montgomery, a player of uncertain defensive ability.
It was a move that allowed Cullen extra freedom.
"It kept us away from a strong defender in Henry Honiball and let Frankie have a one-on-one with Percival," said Ieremia.
"And we tried to use Christian outside Buncy. Percy wasn't a one-out defender. We knew if we could contain him and Honiball in the middle, that the outside lane would be available for Christian.
"So we tried to use that a lot."
The day was not all roses for Cullen, however.
He had a second quarter to forget, when he contributed to two South African tries by firstly losing the ball in a tackle and then not quite getting to a high kick on the full.
Gary Teichmann's try came when Cullen was tackled and bounced the ball, instead of placing it. The Springbok No 8 toed the loose ball ahead and picked up a lucky bounce to run clear and score.
"Just a freak bounce, I guess," said Cullen. "I'll take the blame for it. I don't mind."
The second try came from a miscued Montgomery bomb which bounced and was regained by the kicker. It was a fullback's nightmare -- even the kicker didn't know where the ball was going.
"He was kicking for the corner, I was going the wrong way and I just couldn't get there. It caught everybody off-foot, we were all caught on the wrong foot. I'll take the blame," said Cullen.
The fullback also shared the All Blacks' disappointment at conceding five tries.
"We could have beaten them 55-20 except for those soft tries. We made a lot of mistakes. Thirty-five points is too high. So we're not overly happy."
